The billows of life are supprest,</br>Its tumults, its toils disappear,</br>To relinquish the storms that are past,</br>I think on the sunshine that's near.
Dame Fortune and I are agreed;</br>Her frowns I no longer endure:</br>For the Goddess has kindly decreed,</br>That Damon no more shall be poor.
Now riches will ope the dim eyes,</br>To view the increase of my store;</br>And many my friendship will prize</br>Who never knew Damon before.
But those I renounce and abjure,</br>Who carried contempt in their eye:</br>May poverty still be their dow'r</br>That could look on misfortune awry!
Ye pow'rs that weak mortals govern,</br>Keep pride at his bay from my mind;</br>O let me not haughtily learn</br>To despise the few friends that were kind:
For theirs was a feeling sincere;</br>'Twas free from delusion and art;</br>O may I that friendship revere,</br>And hold it yet dear to my heart:
By which was I ever forgot;</br>It was both my physician and cure,</br>That still found the way to my cot,</br>Altho' I was wretched and poor:
'Twas balm to my canker-tooth'd care;</br>The wound of affliction it heal'd;</br>In distress it was Pity's soft tear,</br>When naked cold Poverty's shield.
Attend, ye kind youth of the plain!</br>Who oft with my sorrows condol'd;</br>You cannot be deaf to the strain,</br>Since Damon is master of gold.
I have chose a soft sylvan retreat,</br>Bedeck'd with the beauties of spring;</br>Around my flocks wander and bleat,</br>While the musical choristers sing.
I force not the waters to stand</br>In an artful canal at my door,</br>But a river at Nature's command,</br>Meanders both limpid and pure.
She's the Goddess that darkens my bow'rs</br>With tendrils of joy and of vine;</br>She tutors my shrubs and my flow'rs,</br>Her taste is the standard of mine.
What a pleasing diversified group</br>Of trees taught has she spread o'er my ground!</br>She has taught the grave laryx to droop,</br>And the birch to deal odours around.
For whom has she perfum'd my groves?</br>For whom has she cluster'd my vine?</br>If friendship despise my alcoves,</br>They'll ne'er be recesses of mine.
He who tastes his grape juices by stealth,</br>Without chosen companions to share,</br>Is the basest of slaves to his wealth,</br>And the pitiful minion of care.
O come!  and with Damon retire</br>Amidst the green umbrage embower'd;</br>Your mirth and your songs to inspire,</br>Shall the juice of his vintage be pour'd?
O come, ye dear friends of his youth!</br>Of all his good fortune partake;</br>Nor think 'tis departing from truth,</br>To say 'twas preserv'd for you sake.</br>
